title: 112_hr6205
content:
The "Protect and Save Act of 2012" allows for the disclosure of tax return information in federal and state law enforcement proceedings. The "Protect and Save Act of 2012" permits the disclosure of tax return information for investigations related to identity theft and fraudulent tax returns by federal and state law enforcement agencies. The "Protect and Save Act of 2012" allows disclosure of tax return information for investigations of crimes related to identity theft and fraudulent tax returns by law enforcement agencies, specifically when working with the Internal Revenue Service. The disclosed information is limited to use within the investigation team and must be requested by the head of the agency involved, providing specific reasons for relevance. The "Protect and Save Act of 2012" allows disclosure of tax return information for investigations of crimes like identity theft and fraudulent tax returns by law enforcement agencies. The Secretary determines whether to grant the disclosure request within 30 days, expediting in cases of murder, murder for hire, or arson. Conforming amendments are made to sections 6103(a) and 6103(p) of the Code. The amendment made by the "Protect and Save Act of 2012" allows for disclosure of tax return information for investigations of crimes like identity theft and fraudulent tax returns by law enforcement agencies. The amendment also clarifies that Federal law enforcement officials can coordinate with State and local law enforcement agencies already investigating related crimes. SEC. 3. LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT LIAISON.

The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to establish the position of Local Law Enforcement Liaison within the Criminal Investigation Division of the IRS. The liaison will coordinate tax fraud investigations with state and local law enforcement agencies, communicate on tax fraud cases involving identity theft, and perform other duties as assigned by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. 

SEC. 4. PIN SYSTEM FOR PREVENTION OF IDENTITY THEFT TAX FRAUD. The Secretary of the Treasury must implement an identity theft tax fraud prevention program within a year of this Act. This program allows individuals to request a unique personal identification number for their tax returns or prevent the processing of electronic tax returns without this number. Additional identity verification safeguards will be provided for tax returns without the unique personal identification number. The program allows individuals to request a unique personal identification number for their tax returns to prevent fraud. SEC. 5. The Comptroller General will study prepaid debit cards and tax software in tax fraud. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees. SEC. 6. A study will be conducted on e-filing in tax fraud. SEC. 6. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the role of e-filing in tax fraud, focusing on identity theft. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees within 6 months. The Secretary of Commerce restricts access to Death Master File information for individuals who have died in the past two years unless certified under a fraud prevention program. The penalty for disclosing or using restricted information from the Death Master File without certification is $1,000 per violation, not to exceed $50,000 in a calendar year. The Social Security Administration is not required to disclose certain records of deceased individuals to uncertified persons. The information in subsection (a) must not be disclosed to uncertified individuals. This section is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 8. Extension of authority to disclose certain return information to prison officials. Section 6103(k)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address prison tax fraud. The Federal Bureau of Prisons must submit a plan to Congress on utilizing information from the Secretary of Treasury to combat fraud. State prison authorities are encouraged to develop plans and coordinate with the IRS to reduce prison tax fraud. The Treasury must report on barriers to information sharing related to identity theft. The Secretary of the Treasury will review current tax laws to assess if they hinder the enforcement of identity theft statutes. Consultation with State and local law enforcement officials will be conducted to improve information sharing for better enforcement of criminal laws. The Secretary of the Treasury will review tax laws to assess impact on identity theft enforcement. Results will be reported to Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees within 180 days.
